title: 104_hr839
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Regulating our Small Businesses Act of 1995" and includes a moratorium on regulations. The "Stop Regulating our Small Businesses Act of 1995" includes a moratorium on regulations for small businesses. Federal agencies are prohibited from taking regulatory rulemaking actions unless an exception is provided. The effectiveness of any regulatory rulemaking action taken during the moratorium period will be suspended until February 1, 1996. The President is required to conduct an inventory of all regulatory rulemaking actions covered by the moratorium. Additionally, there is a special rule on statutory, regulatory, and judicial deadlines. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULE ON STATUTORY, REGULATORY, AND JUDICIAL DEADLINES. Any deadline for actions dependent upon small business regulatory rulemaking is extended until February 1, 1996. Deadline refers to specific dates for fulfilling obligations under Federal statutes or regulations. The President must identify and publish postponed deadlines within 30 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. EMERGENCY EXCEPTIONS; EXCLUSIONS. The head of a Federal agency can request a waiver from regulatory rulemaking actions in cases of imminent threats to health or safety, emergencies, or enforcement of criminal laws. The President must approve the waiver by Executive order, and the agency head must publish the finding and waiver in the Federal Register. Excluded actions due to certification under section 5(4)(B) must be published in the Federal Register. For purposes of this Act, "Federal agency" refers to any agency defined in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. The "moratorium period" is from February 3, 1995, to January 31, 1996. A "small business" is one with 100 or fewer employees. A "regulatory rulemaking action" includes the issuance of substantive rules, interpretative rules, and agency policy statements. The term "regulatory rulemaking" includes actions in the process of rulemaking, excluding certain agency actions certified to reduce regulatory burdens or limited to specific matters. The term "rule" refers to an agency statement that implements, interprets, or prescribes law or policy, excluding certain matters like rates, wages, prices, or accounting practices. The term "license" refers to an agency permit, approval, registration, or other form of permission. Rulemaking is the agency process for formulating, amending, or repealing a rule. SEC. 6. CIVIL ACTION. Whoever is adversely affected by a Federal agency's violation of this Act may seek relief through a civil action against the agency, including reasonable attorney's fees for the prevailing plaintiff. SEC. 7. This Act applies regardless of other laws, and if any part is deemed invalid, the rest remains unaffected.
